name: muscari-armeniacum
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: This plant produces 3-lobed capsules that are green to brown in color. In fruit, the capsules are scattered on the inflorescence axis, the round black seeds that are produced can take up to 4 years to produce blooms.
flower-description: Flowers are numerous, royal blue with a thin white rim on each bell, urceolate, fragrant, and nodding in dense 1"-3" scapose racemes. The perianth fused most of the length, lobes are minute, paler, or white. Sterile flowers usually appear on the upper part of the raceme and are few in number, smaller, and paler. Flowers bloom in mid-spring (April/May).  Some cultivars exist with pink flowers.
leaf-description: Narrow, linear, fleshy, basal, green leaves, grass-like, (to 12 inches long and less than an inch wide) that appear in autumn and live through winter to spring when the plants flower and are often equal to exceeding scape.  They are slightly cupped and may be a bit glaucous.
